choices.text: Contains cells with perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization called koilocytes
Causative agents are usually human papilloma virus (HPV) types 16 & 18
Histologically papillary architecture and acanthosis is seen
Can affect any moist mucocutaneous surface of external genitalia of either sex

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with a wart on his penis noticed 2 weeks back. On biopsy it was found to be condyloma acuminatum. Which of the following statements is false regarding it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Condyloma acuminatum is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11.

  • Condyloma acuminatum is a benign genital wart caused by low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV), most commonly types 6 and 11.
  • It can develop on any moist mucocutaneous area of the external genitalia in both males and females. (Option D ruled out)
  • It presents as a soft, papillomatous, exophytic lesion that often occurs on the vulva, perineum, vagina, cervix, or perianal region.
  • Microscopically, these lesions show branching papillary structures lined by thickened squamous epithelium. Enlarged cells with irregular, wrinkled nuclei surrounded by a clear cytoplasmic halo can be seen which is known as koilocytosis.The lesion can be covered by epithelium with prominent superficial hyperkeratosis (acanthosis). (Options A and C ruled out)
  • Though benign and not considered precancerous, condylomas may recur and are typically managed with topical treatments or surgical removal.

choices.text: Also called carcinoma in situ of penis
Transforms to infiltrating squamous cell cancer in 50% cases
Associated with high risk HPV, especially HPV 16
Contains dysplastic squamous cells containing large hyperchromatic nuclei and lacking orderly maturation

questions.text: False statement about Bowen disease
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transforms to invasive SCC in 10% cases.

choices.text: Presents as multiple reddish-brown popular lesions
Histology is same as Bowen disease

questions.text: Which of the following are true statements about Bowenoid papulosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the given statements about bowenoid papulosis are true.

  • Bowenoid papulosis appears in sexually active individuals, typically at a younger age compared to Bowen disease.
  • It is characterized by multiple reddish-brown papules rather than a solitary lesion.
  • Despite being caused by HPV 16 and having similar histology as that of Bowen disease, bowenoid papulosis never progresses to invasive cancer and often resolves on its own.

choices.text: Divided into HPV related and non-HPV related categories
Non-HPV related cancers are well differentiated like verrucous carcinoma which almost always metastasizes
HPV related cancers are poorly differentiated like basaloid carcinoma
Only 50% of enlarged inguinal nodes in men with penile cancer contain cancer

questions.text: False statement about Penile cancer
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Verrucous carcinoma rarely metastasizes but it invades locally along a broad pushing border.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male has presented to the OPD with complaints of a grey-white lesion on the penile shaft since the past four months. Physical examination reveals a solitary 0.8 cm, plaque like lesion on the distal shaft of the penis. A routine microbiologic culture with a Gram-stained smear of the lesion shows normal skin flora. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen of the lesion shows dysplasia as shown in the histopathological image given below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette along with the histopathological image showing dysplasia suggests a diagnosis of Bowen disease.

  • Bowen disease typically affects older men and is commonly seen on the penile shaft and scrotum, where it presents as a single, thickened, opaque gray-white plaque.
  • It is associated with high-risk human papilloma virus (HPV), more commonly HPV 16.
  • When it occurs on the glans, the lesion tends to appear velvety red.
  • Microscopically, it consists of dysplastic squamous cells with prominent, irregular hyperchromatic nuclei and disorganized maturation, along with frequent atypical mitotic figures. It is considered as a variant of squamous cell cancer in situ and in approximately 10% of cases, it can progress to invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Balanitis (Option A): Balanitis refers to inflammation of the glans penis typically due to infections with Candida albicans, anaerobic bacteria, or Gardnerella. Poor genital hygiene, particularly in uncircumcised men, promotes the accumulation of smegma (desquamated cells, sweat, and debris) which acts as an irritant and predisposes to infection.

Condyloma acuminatum (Option C): Condyloma acuminatum is a benign, sexually transmitted growth caused by HPV and typically affect the external genitalia or perineal region, especially the coronal sulcus and inner preputial surface in males. They appear as single or multiple red papillary growths that are sessile or pedunculated and measure a few millimeters. Microscopically, they exhibit branching papillary stroma with epithelial covering that shows hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and preserved maturation. Koilocytosis, a hallmark of HPV infection, is frequently seen as perinuclear vacuolization in the epithelial cells.

Primary syphilis (Option D): Primary syphilis typically arises about three weeks following infection and presents as a solitary, firm, painless, elevated red lesion (chancre) at the point where Treponema pallidum enters the body. This lesion can appear on various mucocutaneous sites such as the penis, cervix, vaginal wall, or anus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with a solitary plaque over the shaft of the penis present since the last three months. On examination, no inguinal lymphadenopathy is noted. Punch biopsy from the lesion was taken and histopathological image is shown below. Based on these findings, which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette along with the histopathological image showing dysplasia but no invasion of the basement membrane suggests a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma in situ.

  • Squamous cell carcinoma in situ, also termed penile intraepithelial neoplasia (PeIN), includes a spectrum of epithelial lesions restricted to the epidermis.
  • PeIN can be HPV-related (undifferentiated) or non-HPV-related (differentiated) and commonly presents in old age as a solitary plaque on the shaft of the penis.
  • The HPV-associated form is seen in younger adults and is typically linked to high-risk HPV types like HPV 16.
  • Bowen disease, one presentation of PeIN, usually affects older men and appears as thickened gray-white plaques on the penile shaft or scrotum, showing dysplastic squamous cells with atypical mitoses.
  • In contrast, bowenoid papulosis presents in sexually active individuals as multiple reddish-brown papules, histologically similar to Bowen disease but clinically benign, often regressing spontaneously.
  • Invasive squamous cell carcinoma, on the other hand, affects middle-aged and elderly men, particularly in areas with poor genital hygiene and low circumcision rates.
  • WHO classifies penile SCC into HPV-related and non-HPV-related types with distinct morphologies and prognostic implications. Morphologically, these tumors can appear as irregular masses, flat indurated lesions, or cauliflower-like growths.
  • Invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the penis typically progresses slowly and remains localized for an extended period, often going unnoticed for over a year. These lesions are usually painless unless they develop ulceration or become infected.
  • Early metastasis to inguinal lymph nodes can occur, though widespread spread is uncommon unless the disease is very advanced.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a warty, well-differentiated, exophytic, non-HPV variant of squamous cell carcinoma with broad local invasion but low metastatic risk. (Option C ruled out)
  • In contrast, basaloid carcinoma is HPV-related and characterized by poorly differentiated hyperchromatic cells, showing aggressive behavior with destructive invasion.

Explanation of other options:

Invasive squamous cell carcinoma (Option B): Since the basement membrane is not breached, this option can be ruled out.

Peyronie disease (Option D): A non-cancerous condition marked by the formation of firm plaques within the penis, caused by collagen buildup in the connective tissue between the corpora cavernosa and the tunica albuginea. Clinically, it leads to penile bending toward the affected side and may cause pain during sexual activity. Treatment approaches include surgical removal or enzymatic breakdown of the plaques using collagenase.

choices.text: Most common site of arrest of testicular descent is inguinal canal
Thickening of basement membrane of spermatic tubules is seen in early stages
Sertoli cells are spared and therefore relatively prominent.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant went for routine vaccination and his pediatrician found scrotal sacs empty on both sides. Which of the following is a false statement regarding cryptorchidism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leydig cells are spared in cryptorchidism while the tubules containing Sertoli cells become scarred and appear as dense cords of hyaline connective tissue associated with a concomitant increase in interstitial stroma.

  • Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotal sac, either partially or completely, and is associated with impaired testicular function and a heightened risk of developing testicular cancer. (Option A ruled out)
  • It affects roughly 1% of boys by one year of age and often presents as an isolated finding, though it may also accompany other anomalies of the genitourinary tract, such as hypospadias.
  • The descent of the testes occurs in two hormonally controlled phases: the transabdominal phase regulated by müllerian-inhibiting substance, and the inguinoscrotal phase, which is androgen-dependent and mediated by neuropeptides like calcitonin gene-related peptide.
  • Arrest in descent can happen anywhere along the path, most commonly in the inguinal canal, while abdominal arrest is less frequent. (Option B ruled out)
  • Morphologically, cryptorchid testes are generally small, firm, and often unilateral, though bilateral involvement occurs in 25% of cases.
  • Histological abnormalities can begin as early as 2 years of age and include thickening of the basement membrane of seminiferous tubules, loss of spermatogonia, and hyalinization of the tubules, leaving only Sertoli cells. (Option C ruled out)
  • Interstitial stromal proliferation is also observed, while Leydig cells are typically preserved. Interestingly, similar histologic changes may occur in the contralateral descended testis in unilateral cases, indicating a fundamental defect in gonadal development.
  • Clinically, cryptorchidism is asymptomatic and is often first noticed when the scrotum is found to be empty. It may be associated with complications like inguinal hernia or trauma-induced injuries.
  • While spontaneous descent is common during the first year, persistent undescended testes require surgical repositioning via orchiopexy, ideally between 6 - 12 months of age, to reduce the risk of infertility and malignancy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old baby is incidentally detected to have bilateral undescended testes on USG. Surgical repositioning via orchidopexy is planned. What are the possible histological changes that can be expected in such testes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the given findings can be seen in undescended testes.

Histological changes may start as early as age two and involve basement membrane thickening in the seminiferous tubules, , and tubule hyalinization, often resulting in the presence of only Sertoli cells.

There is also an increase in interstitial stromal tissue, although leydig cells usually remain unaffected. Notably, the same histological alterations can be seen in the opposite, normally descended testis in unilateral cases, suggesting an underlying defect in testicular development.

Cryptorchidism is the incomplete descent of one or both testes into the scrotal sac, often linked to impaired testicular function and a heightened risk of malignancy. It is most frequently seen on one side, though both testes are affected in about a quarter of cases, and the affected testes are typically small and firm. This condition is also associated with other anomalies of the genitourinary tract such as hypospadias. Testicular descent occurs in two hormone-regulated stages: the transabdominal and inguinoscrotal phases and may halt at any point, with the inguinal canal being the most frequent site of arrest.

questions.text: Which is not a germ cell tumor derived from germ cell neoplasia in situ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the germ cell tumours arise from germ cell neoplasia in situ except for spermatocytic tumor.

  • The pathogenesis of germ cell tumors begins with a defective differentiation of primordial germ cells, leading to activation of tyrosine kinase pathways, especially via mutations in the KIT gene.
  • This triggers the development of a precursor lesion termed germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS).
  • GCNIS is present in approximately 90% of testes with germ cell neoplasms and is associated with all germ cell tumor subtypes except spermatocytic tumors and some pediatric variants such as prepubertal teratoma and pre-pubertal yolk sac tumor.
  • GCNIS is commonly found in high-risk testes (e.g., cryptorchid testes), often arises during fetal development, and remains dormant until puberty when hormonal changes stimulate tumor growth.
  • The advancement to fully developed germ cell tumors is closely linked to the duplication of the short arm of chromosome 12, known as isochromosome 12p which is a genetic abnormality that is consistently present in invasive GCTs, irrespective of their histologic subtype.
  • GCTs are broadly divided into two categories:Seminomatous tumors which are composed of cells resembling primordial germ cells or gonocytes and non-seminomatous tumors. (Option B ruled out)
  • The latter consist of embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumors, choriocarcinoma, and teratomas. (Options C and D ruled out)
  • Germ cell tumors are also linked to testicular dysgenesis syndrome (TDS), which includes cryptorchidism, hypospadias, and poor semen quality.
  • In utero exposure to environmental estrogens and pesticides is thought to increase risk. Klinefelter syndrome significantly raises the risk of mediastinal (but not testicular) germ cell tumors.

questions.text: Components of testicular dysgenesis syndrome are all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypospadias is a component, not epispadias.

questions.text: Reduplication of which chromosome is found invariably in invasive GCTs regardless of histologic subtype
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isochromosome 12p, a cytogenetic alteration that is invariably in invasive GCTs regardless of histologic subtype.

questions.text: On IHC seminoma cells will stain positive for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Seminoma cells stain positive for OCT 3/4 , KIT, and podoplanin.

  • Seminoma is the most frequently occurring type of germ cell tumor (GCT), accounting for nearly half of all such tumors.
  • It is most commonly diagnosed in individuals in their 30s. A similar tumor occurring in the ovary is termed dysgerminoma, while in the central nervous system (particularly midline locations like the pineal gland), it is referred to as germinoma.
  • Seminomas typically form large masses that can grow up to ten times larger than the normal testis.
  • These tumors usually have a smooth, grayish-white, lobulated cut surface without hemorrhage or necrosis. Although the tunica albuginea often remains intact, some tumors may extend to adjacent structures such as the epididymis, spermatic cord, or even the scrotum.
  • Microscopically, seminomas consist of uniform cells arranged in lobules separated by fine fibrous septa, often with an infiltrate of lymphocytes.
  • The hallmark seminoma cell is round or polyhedral with a well-defined membrane, abundant clear or watery cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus containing one or two prominent nucleoli. These cells are rich in glycogen.
  • Immunohistochemically, seminoma cells express markers like KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin but are negative for cytokeratin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male to surgery OPD with complaints of painless testicular enlargement. A biopsy was taken and histopathological findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario along with histopathological image showing uniform cells arranged in lobules separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytic infiltrates suggests a diagnosis of seminoma.

  • Seminoma is the most prevalent type of germ cell tumor (GCT), making up approximately 50% of all cases. It generally presents in men in their 30s.
  • These tumors often present as bulky masses, at times enlarging the testis to ten times its normal size.
  • The cut surface appears gray-white, lobulated, and typically lacks evidence of hemorrhage or necrosis as shown below.
  • While the tunica albuginea is usually not breached, tumor spread can occasionally involve structures such as the epididymis, spermatic cord, or scrotal sac.
  • On microscopic examination, seminomas show uniform cells organized in lobules divided by delicate fibrous septa, frequently accompanied by a lymphocytic infiltrate.
  • The characteristic seminoma cell is round to polygonal, has a clearly defined cell border, a clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli. These cells are glycogen-rich.
  • Immunohistochemical staining reveals that seminoma cells are positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin, but do not express cytokeratin.

Explanations of other options:

Spermatocytic tumor (Option A): Spermatocytic tumors are well-circumscribed, soft, and occasionally exhibit a gelatinous appearance with cystic areas. Histologically, they consist of three distinct intermingled cell types: medium-sized cells with round nuclei, smaller cells with dense chromatin, and scattered giant cells.

Embryonal carcinoma (Option C): Embryonal carcinomas are aggressive tumors that often invade the epididymis or spermatic cord by breaching the tunica albuginea. Grossly, the cut surface shows a variegated appearance due to frequent hemorrhage or necrosis. Microscopically, the tumor cells typically grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes forming papillary projections.

Yolk sac tumor (Option D): Histologically, they are composed of a lace-like (reticular) arrangement of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindle-shaped cells Various patterns can be seen including papillary formations, solid cords, and other uncommon growth architectures. Notably, about half of these tumors contain Schiller-Duval bodies which are structures that resemble primitive glomeruli with a central capillary surrounded by layers of tumor cells.

choices.text: Schiller-Duval bodies are present in all cases
Prepubertal yolk sac tumor is not derived from germ cell neoplasia in situ
Hyaline like globules in tumor cells contain alpha 1 antitrypsin
Tumor cells are positive for cytokeratin

questions.text: False statement about yolk sac tumors among the given options is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Schiller-Duval bodies are seen in only around 50% of cases of yolk sac tumor.

  • Yolk sac tumors, also known as endodermal sinus tumors, are the most frequently occurring testicular tumors in infants and young children under the age of three, and typically have a favorable prognosis in this age group.
  • In contrast, yolk sac tumors arising after puberty are rarely found in a "pure" form and are more commonly seen in conjunction with embryonal carcinoma or other types of germ cell tumors.
  • Histologically, both prepubertal and postpubertal yolk sac tumors exhibit similar features. However prepubertal tumors are not linked to germ cell neoplasia in situ and do not contain other germ cell tumor components. (Option B ruled out)
  • Morphologically, these tumors display a lace-like or reticular arrangement of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindle-shaped cells. A variety of architectural patterns may be observed, including papillary structures, solid cords, and multiple other less frequent arrangements.
  • A characteristic histological feature, found in about half of all cases, is the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies which is used to describe structures resembling primitive glomeruli composed of a central blood vessel surrounded by a mesodermal core and enveloped by tumor cells in a visceral and parietal arrangement.
  • Additionally, eosinophilic hyaline globules containing alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and alpha-1-antitrypsin are commonly seen in the cytoplasm of tumor cells. (Option C ruled out)
  • The expression of AFP serves as a distinctive marker for yolk sac tumor cells. These tumors are also positive for cytokeratin on immunohistochemical staining. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Teratoma with somatic type malignant transformation can lead to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Teratoma with somatic type malignant transformation can lead to squamous cell cancer, adenocarcinoma, and sarcoma.

  • Teratomas are germ cell tumors (GCTs) that consist of a mix of tissue types resembling derivatives of multiple germ layers.
  • They can appear at any age, from infancy to adulthood. Pure forms are common in children and are termed the "prepubertal type."
  • Among pediatric germ cell tumors, teratomas are second in frequency only to yolk sac tumors.
  • Teratomas developing early in life behave differently and are not associated with germ cell neoplasia in situ or the isochromosome 12p alteration, typically following a benign course.
  • Conversely, most adult postpubertal teratomas are considered malignant.
  • In adult males, teratomas often form large masses ranging from 5 to 10 cm and contain various tissue types, giving a heterogeneous appearance with both solid and cystic areas.
  • Histologically, they contain differentiated tissues or organoid structures such as muscle, cartilage, or neural elements.
  • The tissue components may be mature (resembling adult tissues) or immature (sharing features with fetal tissue).
  • Postpubertal teratomas can undergo malignant transformation, leading to somatic-type (non-germ cell) cancers like squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or sarcoma. This is known as teratoma with somatic type malignant transformation. These transformed components are usually resistant to chemotherapy, making surgical removal the only curative option. Such malignancies retain isochromosome 12p, confirming their origin from the teratoma.
  • Prepubertal teratomas differ by forming structures that closely resemble normal tissues. They can present as dermoid cysts with hair, teeth, or skin. Occasionally, they may be mixed with yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: Reinke crystals are found in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reinke crystals are seen in Leydig cell tumors.

  • Leydig cell tumors arise from the interstitial cells of the testis and may develop in both children and adults and are classified under sex-cord stromal tumors.
  • These tumors often secrete androgens, and sometimes estrogens or corticosteroids. The most frequent symptom in affected individuals is testicular enlargement.
  • In some adults, gynecomastia may be the presenting complaint, while in children, hormonal effects such as early onset of puberty (precocious puberty) are more prominent.
  • Leydig cell tumors are linked with conditions such as Klinefelter syndrome, cryptorchidism, and hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma syndrome, the latter being associated with mutations in the fumarate hydratase gene.
  • Morphologically, Leydig cell tumors are typically well-defined nodules under 5 cm in size. They have a golden-brown, uniform appearance on cut section.
  • Microscopically, the tumor cells mimic normal Leydig cells but are larger. They show round to polygonal outlines with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and a centrally located round nucleus.
  • The cytoplasm often contains lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment. A key diagnostic feature seen in about 25% of cases is the presence of rod-shaped inclusions called Reinke crystalloids.

choices.text: EBV positive extra-nodal NK/T cell lymphoma

questions.text: The most common type of testicular lymphoma is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common testicular lymphoma is diffuse large B cell lymphoma.

  • Primary testicular lymphomas are uncommon, comprising around 5% of all testicular tumors.
  • Despite their rarity, they represent the most frequent testicular malignancy in men over the age of 60.
  • These lymphomas are often aggressive and widely disseminated by the time they are detected.
  • Unlike germ cell tumors (GCTs), testicular lymphomas frequently affect both testes and often involve the spermatic cord.
  • The predominant types, in descending order of occurrence, include diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, followed by Burkitt lymphoma, and Epstein-Barr virus-positive extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • A notable feature of testicular lymphomas is their strong tendency to spread to the central nervous system, which is also a common site of recurrence.

choices.text: Tumor shows lobular pattern by fibrous septa containing lymphocytic infiltrate
Tumor cells have clear cytoplasm due to presence of glycogen
Tumor cells are large having abundant cytoplasm, anaplastic and hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli
The cells are round to polyhedral and has a distinct cell membrane

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient complaints of heavy feeling of one of the testis since 8 months duration. Size of the testis is also increasing gradually. Ultrasound are suggestive of mass malignancy. So, patient underwent surgery and on histological examination a diagnosis of seminoma was confirmed and image is shown below. All of the following are histological features of seminoma; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

(a) The lesion is composed of sheets of uniform cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

(b, d) The classic seminoma cell is round to polyhedral and has a distinct cell membrane; clear or wateryappearing cytoplasm; and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli. The cytoplasm contains varying amounts of glycogen.

(c) These are features of embryonal carcinoma.

choices.text: Tumor cells are arranged in mainly lace like (reticular) pattern
Cells shows marked nuclear atypia compared to embryonal carcinoma
Schiller-Duval bodies are seen in 50% of cases

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presented with a 3-week history of heaviness in the right testis which is gradually increasing. On palpation of scrotal sac, the right testis is larger in size and ultrasound reveals a mass in the right testis. He underwent surgery and the histopathological examination reveals findings as shown below. Based on the above findings, find the false statement among the given options.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette and histopathological image is yolk sac tumor and the cells show less nuclear atypia compared to embryonal carcinoma.

  • Yolk sac tumors, also called endodermal sinus tumors, are the most frequently diagnosed testicular neoplasms in infants and young children under 3 years of age, typically associated with an excellent prognosis.
  • In contrast, in postpubertal individuals, yolk sac tumors are seldom found in a pure form and usually coexist with other germ cell tumors such as embryonal carcinoma.
  • Histologically, both pre- and postpubertal yolk sac tumors exhibit similar features. However, prepubertal forms do not arise from intratubular germ cell neoplasia and other germ cell tumor components.
  • Microscopically, these tumors are composed of a meshwork of cuboidal, flattened, or spindle-shaped cells forming lace-like (reticular) patterns, usually with less nuclear atypia than embryonal carcinoma. (Option A ruled out)
  • Additionally, other architectural patterns such as papillary structures, solid sheets, and various rare configurations can be observed.
  • A hallmark feature, present in about 50% of cases, is the Schiller-Duval body, which mimics primitive glomeruli with a central blood vessel surrounded by tumor cells arranged in a visceral and parietal layer. (Option C ruled out)
  • Tumor cells also characteristically contain hyaline globules rich in alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin, serving as important diagnostic markers. (Option D ruled out)
  • Immunohistochemically, tumor cells show positivity for cytokeratin.

choices.text: BPH affects transitional zone of prostate
Glands are lined by two layers of cells, inner columnar and outer layer of cuboidal or flat basal epithelium
Prostatic infarcts with areas of squamous metaplasia may be seen

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with increased urinary frequency and painful micturition. His pelvic USG shows an enlarged prostate and his clinician makes a diagnosis of benign prostatic hyperplasia. (BPH) Which of the following are true statements regarding BPH?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the given statements are true regarding benign prostatic hyperplasia.

  • Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH), also termed nodular hyperplasia, is the most common benign prostatic condition in men over 50 years. It is a non-premalignant lesion.
  • The primary driver of BPH is dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a potent androgen derived from testosterone by the action of type 2 5α-reductase within prostatic stromal cells.
  • DHT promotes the proliferation of stromal cells and decreases epithelial cell death, largely through androgen receptor (AR) activation and upregulation of various growth factors like FGFs and TGF-β.
  • TGF-β specifically supports stromal proliferation while limiting epithelial proliferation. Estrogens also influence pathogenesis by altering androgen responsiveness and promoting growth through mechanisms like apoptosis regulation and aromatase activity.
  • BPH typically leads to prostate enlargement, increasing its weight up to 60 - 100 g or more.
  • It affects the transition zone and may compress the urethra. Nodules differ in texture and color depending on cellular composition. Glandular nodules appear yellow-pink and secrete milky prostatic fluid, while stromal nodules are pale and firm.
  • Microscopically, nodules consist of dilated glands lined by 2 layers - secretory and basal epithelial layers. Infolding may result in papillary structures. The histopathology image is given below
  • In large glands, impaired blood supply can lead to infarcts and possible squamous metaplasia.
  • Symptoms arise from urinary outflow obstruction due to increased prostate size and stromal muscle contraction. Patients often report urinary frequency, nocturia, difficulty initiating or stopping urination, dribbling, dysuria, and retention.
  • Incomplete bladder emptying promotes infections, and in severe cases, acute retention requires catheterization.
  • Medical therapy includes α-adrenergic blockers, which relax prostatic smooth muscle, and 5α-reductase inhibitors, which lower DHT levels and reduce prostate size.
  • Surgical options like TURP were traditionally standard but newer minimally invasive procedures such as high-intensity focused ultrasound, laser ablation, and radiofrequency therapy are increasingly preferred.

choices.text: Malignant glands are bigger than benign glands
Malignant glands are lined by a single layer of cuboidal or columnar cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about prostate cancer histology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct statement about prostate cancer histology among the given options is malignant glands are lined by a single layer of cuboidal or columnar cells.

  • Prostate adenocarcinoma ranks as the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths in men after lung cancer. This malignancy typically affects older men.
  • Both environmental and genetic influences contribute to the development of prostate cancer. The incidence varies with ethnicity and geography. Environmental risks include exposure to carcinogens, inflammation, and a diet rich in animal fats.
  • Genetic factors involve mutations in genes like BRCA2, HOXB13, and genes regulating MYC. Tumors often develop through a sequence starting from prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN), which shares molecular abnormalities with cancer, including TMPRSS2-ERG fusions and PTEN loss.
  • Androgens, particularly dihydrotestosterone (DHT), promote cancer cell growth and survival by activating androgen receptors (AR). Tumors may later become androgen-independent, often due to AR amplification or mutations enabling ligand-independent activity. Additionally, epigenetic silencing of genes like GSTP1 increases susceptibility to carcinogens.
  • Prostatic adenocarcinomas typically arise in the peripheral zone, particularly posteriorly, making them palpable on digital rectal exam.
  • Grossly, they appear firm and gritty. Microscopically, malignant glands are small, crowded, and lined by a single cell layer with large nucleoli.
  • Basal cells are absent, which aids in distinguishing malignant from benign glands using immunohistochemical stains like AMACR.
  • Approximately 80% of cases also display PIN. Perineural invasion and metastasis, especially to bone, are common in advanced disease. Bone metastases are characteristically osteoblastic. The most common site is the axial skeleton, particularly the lumbar spine.
  • The Gleason grading system stratifies tumors into five prognostic grade groups based on glandular architecture.
  • Early-stage cancers are usually asymptomatic, detected via PSA testing or rectal exam. Later stages can cause urinary obstruction, especially if centrally located. PSA levels, though widely used for screening and monitoring, have limitations due to overlaps with benign conditions like BPH.

questions.text: Most common site of bone metastasis in prostate cancer
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lumbar spine > Proximal femur > Pelvis > Thoracic spine > Ribs

choices.text: AMACR is upregulated in majority of prostate cancers
Glands in prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia lack basal cell layer
Grade and stage are most important prognostic factors
Gleason system is used for grading

questions.text: Which of the following statements about prostate cancer is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Prostatic adenocarcinoma is one of the common malignancies seen in older men and it frequently arises from the peripheral zone.
  • On gross examination, the tumor tissue tends to be firm and gritty, although it may not be easily distinguishable visually.
  • Microscopically, adenocarcinomas are composed of small, well-formed glands that are usually smaller than benign glands and arranged in recognizable architectural patterns.
  • These malignant glands are lined by a single layer of uniform cuboidal or low columnar cells and notably lack papillary infoldings or branching seen in noncancerous glands. One key diagnostic clue is the absence of the outer basal cell layer, which is present in benign glands.
  • Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN), observed in roughly 80% of prostate cancer specimens, serves as a precursor lesion. PIN features large, architecturally benign-appearing glands lined by atypical cells with large nucleoli, but unlike cancer, these still retain at least some basal cell layer and an intact basement membran
  • Histological diagnosis on needle biopsy can be challenging due to the limited amount of tissue, presence of benign glands mixed with malignant ones, and the subtlety of some malignant features.
  • Immunohistochemistry helps differentiate benign from malignant tissue by highlighting the absence of basal cells in cancer. Markers like α-methylacyl coenzyme A racemase (AMACR), which is overexpressed in most prostate cancers, enhance diagnostic sensitivity. (Option A ruled out)
  • Grade and stage are the two most important prognostic factors considered in prostate cancer. Grading is done using Gleason score. (Options C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Gleason grade group 1 used in prostate cancer has a score of less than or equal to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the Gleason system, grade group 1 has a score less than or equal to 6.

The Gleason grading system stratifies prostate cancer based on glandular architecture into five grade groups which help predict prognosis and guide treatment decisions:

Grade Group 1 (Gleason score ≤ 6): Tumors consist solely of individual, well-formed, and discrete glandular structures. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)

Grade Group 2 (Gleason score 3 + 4): The predominant component is made up of well-formed glands, but there is also a minor portion consisting of fused, cribriform, or poorly formed glands.

Grade Group 3 (Gleason score 4 + 3): In contrast to Grade Group 2, these tumors predominantly exhibit fused, cribriform, or poorly differentiated glands, with only a small portion of well-formed glandular structures.

Grade Group 4 (Gleason score 4 + 4 / 3 + 5 / 5 + 3): These tumors consist almost entirely of poorly formed, fused, or cribriform glands. Alternatively, they may show a significant mix of these with an overall loss of glandular formation.

Grade Group 5 (Gleason score 4 + 5 / 5 + 4 / 5 + 5): There is complete absence of gland formation, sometimes with areas of necrosis. If any glands are present, they are exclusively of poorly formed, fused, or cribriform type.

questions.text: Germ cell neoplasia situ seen in all of the following germ cell tumor except
questions.solution: Explanation:

questions.text: Needle biopsy of prostate shows acinar adenocarcinoma. Predominantly in cribriform pattern followed by cells with central necrosis. What is the grade it belongs to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Changes in 2019 Gleason score

Discontinued Gleason grades 1 and 2

  • Gleason grade 3: Single, separate glands
  • Gleason grade 4: Key finding is coalescent or fused glands with > 1 lumen and absence of intervening stroma between adjacent glands. Patterns included are
    • Cribriform
    • Glomeruloid pattern
  • Grade 5 has 2 patterns:
    • Comedonecrosis: central necrosis with intraluminal necrotic cells
    • Single cells, possibly forming cords, possibly with vacuoles (signet ring cells) but without glandular lumens
  • Grade groups are as follows:
    1. Gleason score 3+3=6
    2. Gleason score 3+4=7
    3. Gleason score 4+3=7
    4. Gleason score 8 (4+4=8, 3+5=8, 5+3=8)
    5. Gleason score ≥ 9 (4+5=9, 5+4=9, 5+5=10)

Reference:

Pathology Outlines - Gleason grading

questions.text: A 74-year-old male presents with urinary frequency, nocturia, dribbling, and difficulty in starting and stopping urination. Rectal examination reveals the prostate to be enlarged, firm, and rubbery. Laser-based prostatic chips were removed and sent for histopathological examination shows glands lined by two layer of epithelium, image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

(a) There is absence of inflammation and thickening of basement membrane of glands and arranged in lobules around the duct.

(b) Histologically, the hyperplastic nodules are composed of a variable mixture of hyperplastic glands and hyperplastic stromal cells. Glands are lined by two layer of epithelium.

(c) Prostatic adenocarcinoma consistes of small glands and histologically these malignant glands are composed of a single layer of cuboidal epithelial cells.

(d) PIN will show increased cellularity with moderate pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli.

questions.text: A 67-year-old, previously healthy man presented to his surgeon for a routine health examination. On palpation, there is a nodule in his normal-sized prostate. Laboratory studies show a serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level of 17 ng/mL. A routine urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Subsequent biopsy (TURP) was taken and histopathological image of the same is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical symptoms along with elevated prostate specific antigen (PSA) and histopathology showing small malignant glands lined by a single layer of cells suggests a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma.

  • Prostate adenocarcinoma is the second most common cause of cancer-related mortality in men, following lung cancer, and predominantly affects elderly males.
  • Genetically, alterations in several genes such as BRCA2, HOXB13, and those controlling MYC expression increase susceptibility. The tumor often arises through a precursor lesion known as prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN).
  • Androgens, especially dihydrotestosterone (DHT), play a pivotal role by activating androgen receptors (AR), stimulating tumor growth and survival.
  • These tumors usually originate in the peripheral zone of the prostate, particularly the posterior region, making them accessible to digital rectal examination.
  • On gross examination, they feel firm and gritty. Histologically, they are composed of tightly packed, small malignant glands lined by a single layer of cells with enlarged nucleoli.
  • The absence of basal cells helps distinguish cancerous glands from benign ones, and markers like AMACR are commonly used for confirmation.
  • Advanced disease often shows perineural invasion and metastasis, particularly to bone. The metastatic lesions are usually osteoblastic in nature, favoring the axial skeleton, especially the lumbar spine.

Explanation of other options:

Acute prostatitis (Option A): Acute prostatitis is a sudden inflammation of the prostate usually caused by bacteria similar to those responsible for urinary tract infections. The most frequent pathogen is Escherichia coli, along with other gram-negative rods, enterococci, and staphylococci. Infection often occurs via reflux of contaminated urine from the posterior urethra or bladder, though hematogenous spread from distant sites can also occur. It may also follow instrumentation or procedures involving the urethra or prostate, such as catheterization or cystoscopy. Clinically, it presents with fever, chills, dysuria, and a tender, boggy prostate on digital rectal examination. Diagnosis is based on urine culture and clinical signs. Biopsy is avoided in suspected cases to prevent the risk of sepsis.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (Option B): Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) commonly presents with urinary obstruction symptoms such as difficulty initiating urination, weak stream, nocturia, increased frequency, overflow dribbling, and in severe cases, acute urinary retention requiring catheterization. Histologically, BPH is characterized by hyperplastic nodules composed of proliferating stromal and glandular elements, with glands lined by an inner secretory columnar cell layer and an outer flattened basal cell layer.

Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (Option D): Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) is made up of structurally normal-appearing, large, branching prostatic glands that are lined by atypical epithelial cells with prominent nucleoli, which can appear cytologically similar to cancer cells. However, unlike invasive carcinoma, PIN lesions still maintain at least a partial layer of basal cells and preserve an intact basement membrane.
